subsection.title: Degree and Roots
subsection.p: In this activity, we will explore polynomial functions by building on our knowledge of power functions.

A polynomial polynomial functionpolynomial is a function of the form
f(x) = a_0 + a_1 x + a_2 x^2 + \cdots + a_n x^n
where the numbers a_0 through a_n are constant values, called coefficients. coefficient A polynomial is a sum of a specific set power functions (power functions with non-negative exponents).
First, we will introduce two important terms associated with polynomials: degree and root
The degree polynomialdegree of a polynomial is the highest exponent on the variable.
A root polynomialroot of a polynomial is a value of the input which gives an output of zero.
Test your understanding of these definitions in the next two exercises.

subsection.p: One important note should be made here: Not every polynomial can be written as just a product of linear factors. The function f(x) = x^2 + 1 is an easy example, as it has no x-intercepts. Can you think of other examples? But in this section, we will focus primarily on polynomials which can be written as a product of linear factors.

One skill we will develop here is being able to determine a formula for a polynomial if we have its graph. However, before we can do that, we need to discuss the end-behavior of a polynomial. The end-behavior end-behavior functionend-behavior of a function is what its outputs tend to do as x gets (infinitely) far from zero.

End-behavior is one thing we can tell about the graph of a polynomial, even if it is not written as a product of linear factors, such as:
y = 3x - 5x^2 + 17 \text{or} y = -950x + x^3

subsection.title: End Behavior
subsection.p: Recall that a horizontal asymptote, horizontal asymptote asymptotehorizontal y = a, is a horizontal line which a function f(x) seems to resemble, as either x \to \infty or x \to -\infty.

Put another way, if the function f has a horizontal asymptote y = a, then as we evaluate f(x) at x values which are farther and farther from zero, the outputs will eventually get very close to the number a.

In calculus language, we would write
\lim_{x\to\pm\infty}f(x)=a
and in words, we would say

blockquote.p: The limit of f(x), as x goes to positive or negative infinity, is equal to a.

subsection.p: end-behavior long-run behavior This behavior can be seen in the graph, as the function f(x) appears to flatten out to the left and the right. This is an example of what is called end-behavior (or long-run behavior). From a graphical perspective, end-behavior is what the graph tends to do as the input x gets far from zero.

As you know, not every function has a horizontal asymptote. For example, power functions do not flatten out, but rather they either increase toward \infty (point upward) or decrease toward -\infty (point downward). So, end-behavior may be just that the graph increasing or decreasing forever.
In the next two exercises, you will examine the end-behavior of a polynomial and learn to predict this end-behavior by observing its formula.

solution.p:
Expanding the function g(x) = (x-1)(x+4)(x-5)(x+2) gives:

The leading term, x^4, will have the same end-behavior as g(x).

However, you don't need to completely expand the function in order to see this. Since there are four linear factors, the degree will be 4. In expanding the polynomial, the only way to get x^4 is by multiplying the x from each linear factor. So, the leading term will be just x^4.

subsection.p: The rule for determining the end-behavior of a polynomial is a simple one:

blockquote.p: A polynomial and its leading term have the same end-behavior.

subsection.title: The Formula for a Polynomial
subsection.p:
We have now learned two important things we need in order to write the formula for a polynomial:
the relationship between the roots of a polynomial and its linear factors
the relationship between the end-behavior of a polynomial and its leading term
Let's put these together in order to write the formula for a polynomial.
In the next two exercises, you will be given the graph of a polynomial. Use what you know about the roots and end-behavior in order to write the formula.

statement.p: A polynomial y = f(x) is graphed below. Your goal is to write its formula.
Complete the statement below with a number:
The polynomial will have different linear factors.
Now write the formula for the polynomial.

hint.p: Remember that if a polynomial has an x-intercept at the point (b, 0), then it will have a linear factor of (x - b).
Apply this idea to each of the linear factors.

solution.p:
The x-intercepts are at the points:
(-1, 0) (2, 0) (3, 0)

So, the formula will have the linear factors:
(x + 1) (x - 2) (x - 3)
The formula is: f(x) = (x + 1)(x - 2)(x - 3)

hint.p: Notice the end-behavior looks like -x^3. Remember to incorporate that into your final formula. One idea is to just put a negative symbol outside of the parentheses (like multiplying it all by -1).

solution.p:
Each x-intercept corresponds to a linear factor in the formula:
(-4, 0) \amp\implies (x + 4) (-1, 0) \amp\implies (x + 1) (2, 0) \amp\implies (x - 2)
Also, the end-behavior is the same as -x^3, so our graph needs to be flipped over the x-axis.

The formula is then:
f(x) = -(x+4)(x+1)(x-2) .

We can test that our formula works by using the point (0, 8) shown:
f(0) \amp= -(0 + 4)(0 + 1)(0 - 2) \amp=8

subsection.p: Keep that last exercise in mind when finding a formula for a polynomial. You may need to control the end-behavior by flipping the graph over the x-axis.

subsection.title: Applying Vertical Stretches
subsection.p: There are a few additional things we will encounter with the graph of a polynomial.
The first issue concerns using vertical stretches to the graph of a polynomial (see Chapter).
Imagine trying to determine the formulas for the 3^{\rm{rd}} degree polynomials graphed below.

They each appear to have the same end-behavior as x^3, and they all have the same x-intercepts:
(1, 0)\qquad(3, 0)\qquad(4, 0)

To begin, we will give the formula the necessary linear factors:
f(x) = (x-1)(x-3)(x-4)
because this gives us the correct roots and end-behavior. However, the graphs are not identical, so this formula cannot work for all of them.
Since these graphs all have the same roots of 1, 3 and 4, we might consider examining a different input value.
Fix your attention on the value x = 2 for each graph.

statement.p: Our guess for the formula, f(x) = (x-1)(x-3)(x-4), actually matches one of the graphs. Use the input value x = 2 to decide which of the graphs matches our formula.
Answer:

hint.p: Substitute x = 2 into our formula, and see which graph has the same output value.

solution.p:
Our formula matches the first graph, because
f(2) \amp= (2-1)(2-3)(2-4) \amp= 2
and the first graph contains the point (2, 2).

subsection.p: But what about the formula for the Second Graph? Its output when x = 2 is 4, which is two times as large as the first graph.
This is a vertical stretch of the first graph, as you saw in Section

statement.p:
The 2^{\rm{nd}} graph is a vertical stretch of the function
f(x) = (x-1)(x-3)(x-4) .
What is the formula for this graph?
Answer: y =

hint.p: All of y values on this graph are 2 times as large as the points on the 1^{\rm{st}} graph.

solution.p:
With a vertical stretch of 2, the formula for this graph is:
y = 2(x-1)(x-3)(x-4)

We can check that this works by substituting x = 2 into this formula:
2(2-1)(2-1)(2-4) = 4
and observing that this works, as the graph contains the point (2, 4).

subsection.p: For the Third Graph, we see the output is 3 when the input is x = 2.
We may be able to tell by what factor the graph of f(x) has been vertically stretched to make this graph, but the next exercise explores an algebraic method for determining the factor.

statement.p:
Recall that a vertical stretch of a function occurs by multiplying the outside of the function by a constant value k:
k\cdot f(x)

So, the formula for the 3^{\rm{rd}} graph should look like
k(x-1)(x-3)(x-4)
for some value k.
We can use the fact that this graph passes through the point (2, 3) to solve for the value k.

Because the y-value is 3 when x = 2, we can write:
k(2-1)(2-3)(2-4) \amp= 3 k(2) \amp= 3 k \amp= \frac{3}{2}
What is the formula for the 3^{\rm{rd}} graph?
Answer: y =

solution.p:
The formula is:
y = \frac{3}{2}(x-1)(x-3)(x-4)

subsection.p: In the next exercise, use this algebraic technique to determine the formula for a different polynomial.

statement.p: The graph below shows a polynomial y = f(x). Answer the questions that follow in order to write the formula for f(x).
Begin the formula with just the linear factors we need in order to have the correct x-intercepts.
For now, we leave a constant number k multiplied outside of those factors.
The formula so far: f(x) = k \cdot
Now to solve for the constant number k, use the point (1, -3) on the graph.
This means that when x = 1, the output should be -3.
So, substitute the value x = 1 into your formula, and write that this equals -3.
You should now have an equation which has only the unknown value k.
Solve for the number k.
Answer: k =
Finally, what is the formula for the function f(x) graphed?
Answer: f(x) =

solution.p:
The required factors are:
x \cdot (x+3) \cdot (x-4)

Using the point (1, -3) in our formula gives:
-3 \amp= k(1)(1+3)(1-4) \amp= k(-12)

Solving the equation
-3 = k(-12)
gives us k = 1/4.

So, the final formula is:
f(x) = \frac{1}{4}x(x+3)(x-4)

subsection.title: Multiplicity of Roots
subsection.p:
The last detail we will encounter involves polynomials with factors such as:
x^2 \text{ or } (x-1)^3 \text{ or } (x+6)^{10}
In particular, we want to determine how having an exponent on a linear factor will affect the graph of the polynomial.
In the final exercises for this activity, you will explore these effects on the graph.

subsection.p:
When a polynomial has a linear factor
(x - a)^k
we say that the root x = a has multiplicity multiplicity of a root rootmultiplicity k.
What is important for us to know, is how the multiplicity of a root affects the graph.

statement.p: Suppose a polynomial g(x) has roots x = 3 and x = 5.

li.p: If the multiplicity of x = 3 is 9, then what will the graph look like near the point (3,0)?
Answer: and
If the multiplicity of x = 5 is 2, then what will the graph look like near the point (5,0)?
Answer: and
At the point (3,0), the graph will cross over the x-axis because the multiplicity is odd, and the graph will be nearly horizontal there, because the multiplicity is large.
At the point (5,0), the graph will bounce off the x-axis because the multiplicity is even, and the graph will still be very curved there, because the mutipliciy is not large.

statement.p: The graph below shows a 5^{\rm{th}} degree polynomial y = f(x).
Write a formula for f(x) below, paying attention to the multiplicity of the roots, and the fact that f(x) is a 5^{\rm{th}} degree polynomial.

hint.p: Start by finding the roots, using them to help write the linear factors of the function. Next, remember to take into account the multiplicity of the roots. Finally, consider whether the graph has been vertically stretched to go through the point shown.

solution.p:
Beginning with the linear factors, and a possible vertical stretch, we have:
f(x) = k(x+2)(x-1)^2(x-3)^2

We know that f(0) = 18, so we use those values to solve for the constant k:
18 \amp= k(0+2)(0-1)^2(0-3)^2 \amp= 18k

Solving gives us k = 1, so the formula for the graph is:
f(x) = (x+2)(x-1)(x-3)
